The dissolved parliament also led to the cancellation of the by-election in Haldimand-Norfolk.

In the previous 2019 federal election, the Liberal Party, led by incumbent Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, lost its majority while winning the most seats in the House of Commons. The Conservative Party remained the Official Opposition, with Andrew Scheer temporarily serving as its leader until he resigned to trigger a leadership election. The Bloc Québécois became the third-largest party, and the New Democratic Party lost seats but retained its status as an official party. The Green Party increased its seats in the House of Commons but failed to secure the required twelve MPs for official party status.

Several MPs have announced that they will not run in the upcoming federal election. The Leaders' Debates Commission has proposed recommendations for future election debates, calling for a permanent and publicly funded commission to organize debates and set criteria for participation.

Among the notable events leading to the election include Trudeau's request for dissolution, the cancellation of a by-election, and the announcement of MPs not running in the election. The Canadian public will select members of the House of Commons for the 44th Canadian Parliament on September 20, 2021.

Solar cycle 25 began in December 2019 with a minimum sunspot number of 1.8 and is expected to continue until around 2030. Initially, there were widely varying predictions regarding the strength of the cycle, from very weak to strong. However, most scientific literature now predicts that solar cycle 25 will be weaker than average. The Solar Cycle 25 Prediction Panel predicted in December 2019 that the cycle would be similar to the previous cycle 24, and the number of sunspots would reach a maximum of 115 in July 2025. 

Early signs of the new cycle included polarward reversed polarity sunspots suggesting a transition to cycle 25 was in process, and in November 2019, two reversed polarity sunspots appeared, signaling the onset of the cycle. Bipolar magnetic regions observed in December 2019 also represented early signs of the new cycle. 

Solar activity has continued to increase throughout 2020 and 2021, with the first C-class and M-class solar flares of cycle 25 taking place in May 2020. By November 2020, flares were taking place on a near-daily basis, and an M4.4 flare on November 29, the strongest of the cycle to date, indicated that the solar cycle would be more active than initially thought. In December 2020, a small coronal mass ejection hit Earth, causing bright aurorae at high latitudes. 

In 2021, an X-class solar flare, the second of the current solar cycle, erupted. An associated coronal mass ejection may graze Earth on October 30 or 31, causing bright aurorae and interfering with satellite communications. The number of spotless days continues to decrease, with 18% of days in 2021 being spotless as of August 28, compared to 52% in 2020 and 75% in 2019. 

Overall, solar cycle 25 is expected to be weaker than average but has shown greater activity than predicted in recent months.

Israel's COVID-19 vaccination programme, dubbed "Give a Shoulder" (Hebrew: לתת כתף), has been hailed for its speed and success in vaccinating a high proportion of its population. As of June 26, 2021, around 64% of eligible Israelis have received at least one dose, and 60% are fully vaccinated, making Israel one of the populations with the highest vaccination rates in the world per capita. The programme focused on the elderly, healthcare workers, and other high-risk groups, and utilized the country's centralized government and health maintenance organizations to coordinate national vaccination drives using databases of personal information to contact residents directly.

In August 2021, Israel rolled out a third dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine to people over the age of 60, based on data showing significant waning immunity from infection over time for those with two doses. The country expanded the availability to all Israelis over the age of 12, five months after their second shot. Israel's coronavirus czar announced that Israelis who had not received a booster shot within six months of their second dose would lose access to the country's green pass vaccine passport.

Recently, Israel's pandemic advisory board approved the usage of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine for children between the ages of 5 and 11. This decision is seen as a significant step in the country's efforts to combat the virus and protect its population, especially as concerns grow about the spread of the highly transmissible Delta variant. 

However, the distribution of vaccines to Palestinians has been less thorough than to Israeli citizens, with many Palestinian laborers receiving their doses only in March 2021. Haredi Jews and Arab-Israelis also had a lower rate of vaccination and were comparatively more likely to be hesitant or skeptical about taking the vaccine. Israeli authorities also faced early distribution issues, including scheduling appointments and lack of sufficient distribution to less-populated villages and Arab-Israeli communities. However, Israel addressed these issues through messaging, incentives, extensions to the initial vaccine delivery system, and other measures.

Despite these challenges, Israel's vaccination programme has produced evidence that the Pfizer vaccine works to stop transmission of the virus, including asymptomatic infections, and curbed deaths in the country. The success of the programme has been credited to the centralized systems its health maintenance organizations maintained and the country's organized response in attaining, storing, and distributing vaccines. With approval for vaccination of children as young as five, Israel continues to prioritize its population's health and safety in its battle against COVID-19.

On 18 November 2021, Tongans headed to the polls to elect 17 out of the 26 seats of the Legislative Assembly of Tonga in the general elections. However, in September 2019, Pohiva passed away, and his successor, Pohiva Tuʻiʻonetoa, became Prime Minister with the support of nobles, independent MPs, and five former members of the DPFI. His cabinet included three nobles who had previously been excluded during Pohiva's tenure.

In December 2020, Democratic Party leader Semisi Sika submitted a motion of no-confidence in Prime Minister Tuʻiʻonetoa. The motion was supported by Deputy Prime Minister Sione Vuna Fa'otusia, who subsequently resigned from Cabinet. However, the Legislative Assembly rejected the no-confidence motion 13-9 on 12 January 2021.

The Tongan electoral system is comprised of up to 30 members, 17 of which are elected directly through first-past-the-post voting from single-member constituencies. The island of Tongatapu has ten constituencies, Vavaʻu three, Haʻapai two, and ʻEua and Niuatoputapu/Niuafoʻou one each. Nine seats are reserved for members of the nobility who elect representatives from amongst themselves. The Cabinet, formed by the Prime Minister, can include up to four members who were not elected to the Assembly, but who automatically become members of the legislature.

A total of 75 candidates, including 12 women, registered to contest the election. However, one candidate, Sione Fonua, withdrew, while another passed away, leaving a total of 73 candidates. Despite a week-long lockdown due to a COVID-19 case, the election was not delayed. Tongans now await the outcome of the election, which will determine the makeup of the new government.

The 2021–2022 European windstorm season marks the seventh instance of seasonal European windstorm naming in Europe. This season is unique as Greece, Israel, and Cyprus (Eastern Mediterranean Group) and Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Montenegro, North Macedonia, and Malta (Central Mediterranean Group) have joined the seasonal naming scheme, naming storms affecting their areas. The Netherlands will also participate for the third time, joining the meteorological agencies of Ireland and the United Kingdom (Western Group), and collaborations between the Portuguese, Spanish, French, and Belgian meteorological agencies will continue, along with the addition of the Luxembourgish meteorological agency (South-western Group).  

The storm names for this season were released on September 1, 2021, and will include any storms that occur until August 31, 2022. Two main naming lists exist, one created by the national meteorological agencies of the Western Group (United Kingdom, Ireland, and the Netherlands) and another created by the equivalent agencies from France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium, and Luxembourg. Former Atlantic hurricanes will retain their names as assigned by the National Hurricane Center of the United States.

The Storm Naming Scheme also includes those systems of tropical origins. For instance, ex-Hurricane Lorenzo of 2019 made landfall in Ireland and the United Kingdom, and all tropical storms and hurricanes can be found on the National Hurricane Centre website. The naming scheme of European storm warnings is part of the "Name our Storms" project, which the Met Office and Met Éireann launched and called for a public suggestion for storm names in 2015. The first list of names for 2015–2016 through to 2017–2018 was created, which was common to both the United Kingdom and Ireland.

Multiple storms have occurred since the commencement of this season. Cyclone Apollo and Storm Blas caused major flooding and landslides in many countries in their pathway, such as the Mediterranean coast, Italy, Libya, and Algeria. Along with this, three people were killed in Algiers, six people in Eastern Sicily and the Balearic Islands, and two people in Germany and Poland. Many places lost power, and extensive damage and travel disruptions were witnessed.

Recently, Storm Arwen hit the British Isles, killing at least three people and causing widespread damage, extensive disruptions in Scotland and North East England, and leaving around 100,000 people without electricity. Red warnings for winds were also issued in North-Eastern parts of the UK, along with extensive orange and yellow warnings throughout Scotland, Northern Ireland, Wales, and most parts of England. Dangerous waves were also predicted, with disruptions to ferry services. On November 26, the Network Rail halted running trains north of Newcastle, and at 5 pm GMT, closed the rail lines north of Berwick-upon-Tweed, due to the alarming situation.

Prior to the shooting, there were reports of a possible mass shooting threat, including an act of vandalism where a deer head was thrown off the school roof. However, school officials investigated and found no evidence of a credible threat.

The shooting began around 12:55 p.m. EST, with the suspect using a SIG Sauer SP2022 semiautomatic handgun. Following the shooting, President Joe Biden and Representative Elissa Slotkin both offered their condolences to the families affected. Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer stated in a press release that she was "devastated" by the incident and called gun violence a "public health crisis." The Semeru volcano in East Java, Indonesia erupted on December 4, resulting in one death and 41 injuries. The eruption occurred when a lava dome at the summit collapsed due to heavy precipitation, triggering a pyroclastic flow that descended the volcano's slopes. The eruption sent a plume of ash 40,000 feet (12,000 meters) into the air and affected six sub-districts in the Malang Regency and eight villages in the Lumajang Regency. The Gladak Perak Bridge was destroyed, blocking access to villages in the area, while power outages affected over 30,000 people. Lahars destroyed at least 30 homes in the Pronojiwo District, and heavy ashfall buried many village homes and vehicles. Some 300 families were evacuated.

Initial reports indicated that three people went missing when the Gladak Perak Bridge collapsed, but the number later increased to 10. One person was killed, and 41 others were injured, with many suffering burns caused by pyroclastic flows. The injured were treated at the Penanggal Health Center, and four of them were in serious condition and admitted to the intensive care unit. On December 5, a second death was confirmed at Dr. Haryoto Hospital due to severe burns. The death toll has since increased to 14, with many of the victims dead from burns.

Authorities have warned residents to stay at least 5 km away from the main summit crater to avoid large pyroclastic flows, while approaching the crater within 1 km is strictly prohibited. Volcanic activity and ashfall continue to be a concern in some villages, and residents are urged to evacuate. Rivers originating from Semeru are also transporting volcanic debris, and residents should avoid them.

As of December 5, over 5,200 people were affected, with 1,300 residents in Lumajang displaced. The BNPB provided meals, ready-to-eat packs, blankets, mattresses, masks, and refugee tents, as well as medical supplies, water, and instant food. The Yogyakarta International Airport, Adisumarmo International Airport, and Abdul Rachman Saleh Airport were unaffected by the eruption.

Indonesian President Joko Widodo visited the Lumajang Regency on December 5 to lead the BNPB in post-eruption recovery efforts, while the Governor of East Java relocated her office to aid in the evacuation process. Rescue operations for missing miners are set to begin once activity on the volcano decreases.

In a tragic incident on 4 December 2021, the Indian Army's Assam Rifles unit mistakenly opened fire on a group of miners returning home from work in Nagaland, India. Believing the miners to be militants, the soldiers killed 13 civilians, while a soldier and seven miners lost their lives in a subsequent confrontation with angry locals. The incident has sparked public outrage in Nagaland, with calls for the repeal of the Armed Forces Special Powers Act (AFSPA).

According to reports, the army had received intelligence regarding the movements of the National Socialist Council of Nagaland (Khaplang-Yung Aung) (NSCN (K-YA)) militants. However, instead of the militants, the army unit killed the innocent coal mine workers returning in a similarly described vehicle.

The Indian government has formed a Special Investigation Team (SIT) to probe the incident, and the Nagaland Police have registered a case against the 21 Para Special Forces. The National Human Rights Commission of India has sent notices to the Central and State governments regarding the incident.

Following the tragedy, protests were organized across Nagaland on 5 December 2021, with more than 200 people attacking and vandalizing the Assam Rifles army camp in Mon Town. Section 144 was imposed in Mon District, with restrictions on public assembly and movement, as well as the suspension of mobile internet and bulk SMS services.

The Eastern Nagaland People’s Organisation (ENPO), which represents six tribes, withdrew from the ongoing annual Hornbill Festival at Kisama near Kohima, while the Nagas hoisted black flags on all Morungs at the festival. On 7 December, the Government of Nagaland announced that it would suspend all activities at the Hornbill Festival and seek the repeal of the Armed Forces Special Powers Act. The incident highlights the need for better training and intelligence, as well as the importance of addressing the concerns of local communities in the northeast of India.

The Australian Open, the first Grand Slam of the year, is set to take place at Melbourne Park from 17-30 January 2022. After being granted a medical exemption from mandatory COVID-19 vaccination by Tennis Australia and the health department of the state of Victoria, Djokovic was detained by the Australian Border Force upon arriving in Australia on 5 January 2022, as his visa did not meet the country's entry requirements for unvaccinated travellers.

Despite requesting an injunction against deportation in order to appeal the visa refusal, the Minister for Immigration and Citizenship, Alex Hawke, used his ministerial powers under the Migration Act 1958 to cancel Djokovic's visa on "health and good order grounds". Djokovic was detained in a detention hotel pending the outcome of the appeal, but on 10 January, the Federal Circuit and Family Court ruled in favour of Djokovic, ordered his release from detention, and directed the federal government to pay his legal expenses. The reason for the ruling was that when Djokovic was in immigration holding before his visa was cancelled, Australian officials reneged on an agreement to give Djokovic sufficient time to contact his lawyers and tennis authorities before his official interview, leading the Australian government to concede that they treated Djokovic unreasonably.

More than two dozen players and staff members had applied for a medical exemption, and a handful of applications had been granted. Among those, two people with the same type of visa and exemption as Djokovic had reportedly been allowed into the country. Player Renata Voráčová, who was one of those granted an exemption, was allowed into the country and participated in a warm-up tournament, but she was subsequently detained in the same hotel as Djokovic and deported on 8 January 2022. A tennis official with an exemption was also allowed entry but left the country voluntarily.

The decision to grant an unvaccinated athlete entry while many Australians remain stranded overseas due to the pandemic, in order to participate in an event that spectators cannot attend unless fully vaccinated, has been met with negative public opinion in Australia.

It was also reported that several gunshots and a loud bang were heard around 9:21 p.m. Later, the assailant was shot and killed by the police.

The incident drew national attention, prompting the attention of the White House, Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett, and Alternate Prime Minister of Israel Yair Lapid. Aafia Siddiqui's attorney stated that she was not involved in the situation and strongly condemned the hostage-taking, urging the assailant to release all hostages and turn himself in.

A massive eruption of the Hunga Tonga volcano in Tonga on January 15, 2022, caused a series of tsunamis across the Pacific Ocean, affecting several countries. The initial eruption occurred on December 20, 2021, after being relatively dormant since 2014, and the volcanic activity increased over time. On January 14, 2022, a large eruption sent clouds of ash 20 kilometers (12 miles) into the atmosphere, and a significantly larger eruption occurred the following day at approximately 17:00. The eruption caused significant seismic activity, sending tsunamis in Tonga, Fiji, Samoa, Vanuatu, New Zealand, Australia, Japan, the United States, Canada, Chile, and Ecuador.

The tsunami caused damage and casualties in several places. In Lambayeque, Peru, two people were killed by a small tsunami. Some islands in Vanuatu observed "destructive" tsunami waves of 1–2.5 meters (3 ft 3 in – 8 ft 2 in), and some areas in the Philippines were put on a tsunami watch. Coastal evacuations were issued in 14 of the 16 regions in Chile, and strong currents were reported in Half Moon Bay, California. Australia's Bureau of Meteorology issued marine and land warnings, and Japan's Meteorological Agency issued a tsunami warning, along with evacuation orders in several prefectures.

The eruption ejected a large amount of volcanic material into the stratosphere, and a scientist from the University of Auckland described it as a one-in-1000-year event. Little information is available on the extent of damage and casualties due to communication issues. Tongan geologists near the volcano observed explosions and a 5-kilometer (3.1 miles) wide ash column. Atata, a small island off the capital city, was reportedly submerged, and rescue operations are underway. There are reports of residents in Tonga struggling to breathe as a result of the ash. The Tonga government has not confirmed any casualties from the eruption and tsunami.

New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said officials in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs are discussing the provision of aid to Tonga, and rescue operations are underway at Atata Island. The Mineral Resources Department in Fiji issued advisories to people living around the coastal areas to stay away from the shores, and evacuations were made on the Lau Islands after wave activity was observed in the sea. Samoa issued a tsunami advisory, and the PTWC issued a warning for American Samoa. The National Tsunami Warning Center issued a tsunami advisory along the West Coast of the United States and British Columbia, Canada, while Hawaii issued a tsunami advisory for the entire state. Beaches were closed, and coastal residents were requested to move to higher grounds.

The Rule of Law Conditionality Regulation, a regulation of the European Union and Euratom aimed at linking disbursements from the European Union's budget to adherence to rule of law standards, has seen a major development. The European Court of Justice has dismissed Hungary and Poland's legal challenges against the regulation, confirming that it is in compliance with the treaties of the European Union. This decision will now allow the European Commission to suspend funds from the EU budget to member states that violate the principles of the rule of law enshrined in article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. The regulation could therefore prove to be a valuable tool in addressing democratic backsliding in Hungary and Poland, which has been a major concern for the European Union since the 2010s. The European Parliament has already called on the Commission to avoid any further delays in its application of the regulation and to keep the Parliament regularly informed.

The fight against terrorism in Australia involves the designation of terrorist organisations by the government, with a list first established under the Security Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Act 2002. The Attorney-General's Department maintains the list, and organisations may be designated as terrorist through court prosecution or by regulation under Division 102 of the Criminal Code Act 1995. As of November 2021, there are 29 foreign organisations on the list, including Atomwaffen Division, Tahrir al-Sham, and the Guardians of Religion Organization. The entirety of Hamas, including its political wing, has also been designated as a terrorist organisation in Australia. Anti-terrorism financing laws in Australia prohibit the financing of terrorism and mandate monitoring of financial transactions involving terrorist organisations by the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (AUSTRAC). Prosecution of terrorism offences falls to the Australian Federal Police, State police forces, and Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions.
